" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002432": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002432", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Pauline, you must cease that sobbing, now, and sleep. You will make yourself ill. La Petite will not go away. Do you hear me? Do you understand? She will stay, I promise you.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002433": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002433", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002434": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002434", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Mam’selle Pauline could not clearly comprehend, but she had great faith in the word of her sister, and soothed by the promise and the touch of Ma’ame Pélagie’s strong, gentle hand, she fell asleep.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002435": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002435", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002436": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002436", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

III

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002437": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002437", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002438": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002438", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Ma’ame Pélagie, when she saw that her sister slept, arose noiselessly and stepped outside upon the low-roofed narrow gallery. She did not linger there, but with a step that was hurried and agitated, she crossed the distance that divided her cabin from the ruin.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002439": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002439", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002440": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002440", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The night was not a dark one, for the sky was clear and the moon resplendent. But light or dark would have made no difference to Ma’ame Pélagie. It was not the first time she had stolen away to the ruin at night-time, when the whole plantation slept; but she never before had been there with a heart so nearly broken. She was going there for the last time to dream her dreams; to see the visions that hitherto had crowded her days and nights, and to bid them farewell.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002441": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002441", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002442": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002442", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

There was the first of them, awaiting her upon the very portal; a robust old white-haired man, chiding her for returning home so late. There are guests to be entertained. Does she not know it? Guests from the city and from the near plantations. Yes, she knows it is late. She had been abroad with Félix, and they did not notice how the time was speeding. Félix is there; he will explain it all. He is there beside her, but she does not want to hear what he will tell her father.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002443": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002443", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002444": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002444", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Ma’ame Pélagie had sunk upon the bench where she and her sister so often came to sit. Turning, she gazed in through the gaping chasm of the window at her side. The interior of the ruin is ablaze. Not with the moonlight, for that is faint beside the other one—the sparkle from the crystal candelabra, which negroes, moving noiselessly and respectfully about, are lighting, one after the other. How the gleam of them reflects and glances from the polished marble pillars!

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002445": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002445", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002446": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002446", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The room holds a number of guests. There is old Monsieur Lucien Santien, leaning against one of the pillars, and laughing at something which Monsieur Lafirme is telling him, till his fat shoulders shake. His son Jules is with him—Jules, who wants to marry her. She laughs. She wonders if Félix has told her father yet. There is young Jérôme Lafirme playing at checkers upon the sofa with Léandre. Little Pauline stands annoying them and disturbing the game. Léandre reproves her. She begins to cry, and old black Clementine, her nurse, who is not far off, limps across the room to pick her up and carry her away. How sensitive the little one is! But she trots about and takes care of herself better than she did a year or two ago, when she fell upon the stone hall floor and raised a great “bo-bo” on her forehead. Pélagie was hurt and angry enough about it; and she ordered rugs and buffalo robes to be brought and laid thick upon the tiles, till the little one’s steps were surer.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002447": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002447", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002448": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002448", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Il ne faut pas faire mal à Pauline.” She was saying it aloud—“faire mal a Pauline.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002449": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002449", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002450": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002450", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

But she gazes beyond the salon, back into the big dining hall, where the white crèpe myrtle grows. Ha! how low that bat has circled. It has struck Ma’ame Pélagie full on the breast. She does not know it. She is beyond there in the dining hall, where her father sits with a group of friends over their wine. As usual they are talking politics. How tiresome! She has heard them say “la guerre” oftener than once. La guerre. Bah! She and Félix have something pleasanter to talk about, out under the oaks, or back in the shadow of the oleanders.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002451": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002451", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002452": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002452", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

But they were right! The sound of a cannon, shot at Sumter, has rolled across the Southern States, and its echo is heard along the whole stretch of Côte Joyeuse.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002453": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002453", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002454": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002454", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Yet Pélagie does not believe it. Not till La Ricaneuse stands before her with bare, black arms akimbo, uttering a volley of vile abuse and of brazen impudence. Pélagie wants to kill her. But yet she will not believe. Not till Félix comes to her in the chamber above the dining hall—there where that trumpet vine hangs—comes to say good-by to her. The hurt which the big brass buttons of his new gray uniform pressed into the tender flesh of her bosom has never left it. She sits upon the sofa, and he beside her, both speechless with pain. That room would not have been altered. Even the sofa would have been there in the same spot, and Ma’ame Pélagie had meant all along, for thirty years, all along, to lie there upon it some day when the time came to die.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002455": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002455", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002456": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002456", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

But there is no time to weep, with the enemy at the door. The door has been no barrier. They are clattering through the halls now, drinking the wines, shattering the crystal and glass, slashing the portraits.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002457": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002457", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002458": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002458", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

One of them stands before her and tells her to leave the house. She slaps his face. How the stigma stands out red as blood upon his blanched cheek!

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002459": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002459", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002460": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002460", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Now there is a roar of fire and the flames are bearing down upon her motionless figure. She wants to show them how a daughter of Louisiana can perish before her conquerors. But little Pauline clings to her knees in an agony of terror. Little Pauline must be saved.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002461": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002461", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002462": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002462", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Il ne faut pas faire mal à Pauline.” Again she is saying it aloud—“faire mal à Pauline.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002463": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002463", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002464": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002464", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The night was nearly spent; Ma’ame Pélagie had glided from the bench upon which she had rested, and for hours lay prone upon the stone flagging, motionless. When she dragged herself to her feet it was to walk like one in a dream. About the great, solemn pillars, one after the other, she reached her arms, and pressed her cheek and her lips upon the senseless brick.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002465": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002465", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002466": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002466", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Adieu, adieu!” whispered Ma’ame Pélagie.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002467": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002467", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002468": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002468", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

There was no longer the moon to guide her steps across the familiar pathway to the cabin. The brightest light in the sky was Venus, that swung low in the east. The bats had ceased to beat their wings about the ruin. Even the mocking-bird that had warbled for hours in the old mulberry-tree had sung himself asleep. That darkest hour before the day was mantling the earth. Ma’ame Pélagie hurried through the wet, clinging grass, beating aside the heavy moss that swept across her face, walking on toward the cabin—toward Pauline. Not once did she look back upon the ruin that brooded like a huge monster—a black spot in the darkness that enveloped it.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002469": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002469", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002470": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002470", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

IV

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002471": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002471", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002472": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002472", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Little more than a year later the transformation which the old Valmêt place had undergone was the talk and wonder of Côte Joyeuse. One would have looked in vain for the ruin; it was no longer there; neither was the log cabin. But out in the open, where the sun shone upon it, and the breezes blew about it, was a shapely structure fashioned from woods that the forests of the State had furnished. It rested upon a solid foundation of brick.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002473": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002473", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002474": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002474", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Upon a corner of the pleasant gallery sat Léandre smoking his afternoon cigar, and chatting with neighbors who had called. This was to be his pied à terre now; the home where his sisters and his daughter dwelt. The laughter of young people was heard out under the trees, and within the house where La Petite was playing upon the piano. With the enthusiasm of a young artist she drew from the keys strains that seemed marvelously beautiful to Mam’selle Pauline, who stood enraptured near her. Mam’selle Pauline had been touched by the re-creation of Valmêt. Her cheek was as full and almost as flushed as La Petite’s. The years were falling away from her.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002475": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002475", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002476": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002476", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Ma’ame Pélagie had been conversing with her brother and his friends. Then she turned and walked away; stopping to listen awhile to the music which La Petite was making. But it was only for a moment. She went on around the curve of the veranda, where she found herself alone. She stayed there, erect, holding to the banister rail and looking out calmly in the distance across the fields.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002477": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002477", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002478": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002478", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She was dressed in black, with the white kerchief she always wore folded across her bosom. Her thick, glossy hair rose like a silver diadem from her brow. In her deep, dark eyes smouldered the light of fires that would never flame. She had grown very old. Years instead of months seemed to have passed over her since the night she bade farewell to her visions.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002479": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002479", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002480": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002480", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Poor Ma’ame Pélagie! How could it be different! While the outward pressure of a young and joyous existence had forced her footsteps into the light, her soul had stayed in the shadow of the ruin.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002481": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002481", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002482": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002482", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002483": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002483", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

DÉSIRÉE’S BABY

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002484": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002484", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002485": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002485", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

As the day was pleasant, Madame Valmondé drove over to L’Abri to see Désirée and the baby.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002486": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002486", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002487": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002487", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

It made her laugh to think of Désirée with a baby. Why, it seemed but yesterday that Désirée was little more than a baby herself; when Monsieur in riding through the gateway of Valmondé had found her lying asleep in the shadow of the big stone pillar.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002488": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002488", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002489": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002489", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The little one awoke in his arms and began to cry for “Dada.” That was as much as she could do or say. Some people thought she might have strayed there of her own accord, for she was of the toddling age. The prevailing belief was that she had been purposely left by a party of Texans, whose canvas-covered wagon, late in the day, had crossed the ferry that Coton Maïs kept, just below the plantation. In time Madame Valmondé abandoned every speculation but the one that Désirée had been sent to her by a beneficent Providence to be the child of her affection, seeing that she was without child of the flesh. For the girl grew to be beautiful and gentle, affectionate and sincere,—the idol of Valmondé.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002490": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002490", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002491": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002491", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

It was no wonder, when she stood one day against the stone pillar in whose shadow she had lain asleep, eighteen years before, that Armand Aubigny riding by and seeing her there, had fallen in love with her. That was the way all the Aubignys fell in love, as if struck by a pistol shot. The wonder was that he had not loved her before; for he had known her since his father brought him home from Paris, a boy of eight, after his mother died there. The passion that awoke in him that day, when he saw her at the gate, swept along like an avalanche, or like a prairie fire, or like anything that drives headlong over all obstacles.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002492": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002492", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002493": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002493", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Monsieur Valmondé grew practical and wanted things well considered: that is, the girl’s obscure origin. Armand looked into her eyes and did not care. He was reminded that she was nameless. What did it matter about a name when he could give her one of the oldest and proudest in Louisiana? He ordered the corbeille from Paris, and contained himself with what patience he could until it arrived; then they were married.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002494": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002494", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002495": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002495", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Madame Valmondé had not seen Désirée and the baby for four weeks. When she reached L’Abri she shuddered at the first sight of it, as she always did. It was a sad looking place, which for many years had not known the gentle presence of a mistress, old Monsieur Aubigny having married and buried his wife in France, and she having loved her own land too well ever to leave it. The roof came down steep and black like a cowl, reaching out beyond the wide galleries that encircled the yellow stuccoed house. Big, solemn oaks grew close to it, and their thick-leaved, far-reaching branches shadowed it like a pall. Young Aubigny’s rule was a strict one, too, and under it his negroes had forgotten how to be gay, as they had been during the old master’s easy-going and indulgent lifetime.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002496": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002496", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002497": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002497", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The young mother was recovering slowly, and lay full length, in her soft white muslins and laces, upon a couch. The baby was beside her, upon her arm, where he had fallen asleep, at her breast. The yellow nurse woman sat beside a window fanning herself.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002498": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002498", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002499": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002499", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Madame Valmondé bent her portly figure over Désirée and kissed her, holding her an instant tenderly in her arms. Then she turned to the child.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002500": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002500", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002501": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002501", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“This is not the baby!” she exclaimed, in startled tones. French was the language spoken at Valmondé in those days.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002502": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002502", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002503": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002503", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“I knew you would be astonished,” laughed Désirée, “at the way he has grown. The little cochon de lait! Look at his legs, mamma, and his hands and finger-nails,—real finger-nails. Zandrine had to cut them this morning. Isn’t it true, Zandrine?”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002504": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002504", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002505": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002505", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The woman bowed her turbaned head majestically, “Mais si, Madame.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002506": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002506", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002507": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002507", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“And the way he cries,” went on Désirée, “is deafening. Armand heard him the other day as far away as La Blanche’s cabin.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002508": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002508", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002509": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002509", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Madame Valmondé had never removed her eyes from the child. She lifted it and walked with it over to the window that was lightest. She scanned the baby narrowly, then looked as searchingly at Zandrine, whose face was turned to gaze across the fields.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002510": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002510", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002511": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002511", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Yes, the child has grown, has changed,” said Madame Valmondé, slowly, as she replaced it beside its mother. “What does Armand say?”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002512": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002512", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002513": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002513", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Désirée’s face became suffused with a glow that was happiness itself.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002514": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002514", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002515": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002515", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Oh, Armand is the proudest father in the parish, I believe, chiefly because it is a boy, to bear his name; though he says not,—that he would have loved a girl as well. But I know it isn’t true. I know he says that to please me. And mamma,” she added, drawing Madame Valmondé’s head down to her, and speaking in a whisper, “he hasn’t punished one of them—not one of them—since baby is born. Even Négrillon, who pretended to have burnt his leg that he might rest from work—he only laughed, and said Négrillon was a great scamp. Oh, mamma, I’m so happy; it frightens me.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002516": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002516", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002517": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002517", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

What Désirée said was true. Marriage, and later the birth of his son had softened Armand Aubigny’s imperious and exacting nature greatly. This was what made the gentle Désirée so happy, for she loved him desperately. When he frowned she trembled, but loved him. When he smiled, she asked no greater blessing of God. But Armand’s dark, handsome face had not often been disfigured by frowns since the day he fell in love with her.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002518": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002518", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002519": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002519", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

When the baby was about three months old, Désirée awoke one day to the conviction that there was something in the air menacing her peace. It was at first too subtle to grasp. It had only been a disquieting suggestion; an air of mystery among the blacks; unexpected visits from far-off neighbors who could hardly account for their coming. Then a strange, an awful change in her husband’s manner, which she dared not ask him to explain. When he spoke to her, it was with averted eyes, from which the old love-light seemed to have gone out. He absented himself from home; and when there, avoided her presence and that of her child, without excuse. And the very spirit of Satan seemed suddenly to take hold of him in his dealings with the slaves. Désirée was miserable enough to die.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002520": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002520", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002521": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002521", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She sat in her room, one hot afternoon, in her peignoir, listlessly drawing through her fingers the strands of her long, silky brown hair that hung about her shoulders. The baby, half naked, lay asleep upon her own great mahogany bed, that was like a sumptuous throne, with its satin-lined half-canopy. One of La Blanche’s little quadroon boys—half naked too—stood fanning the child slowly with a fan of peacock feathers. Désirée’s eyes had been fixed absently and sadly upon the baby, while she was striving to penetrate the threatening mist that she felt closing about her. She looked from her child to the boy who stood beside him, and back again; over and over. “Ah!” It was a cry that she could not help; which she was not conscious of having uttered. The blood turned like ice in her veins, and a clammy moisture gathered upon her face.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002522": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002522", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002523": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002523", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She tried to speak to the little quadroon boy; but no sound would come, at first. When he heard his name uttered, he looked up, and his mistress was pointing to the door. He laid aside the great, soft fan, and obediently stole away, over the polished floor, on his bare tiptoes.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002524": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002524", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002525": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002525", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She stayed motionless, with gaze riveted upon her child, and her face the picture of fright.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002526": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002526", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002527": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002527", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Presently her husband entered the room, and without noticing her, went to a table and began to search among some papers which covered it.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002528": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002528", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002529": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002529", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Armand,” she called to him, in a voice which must have stabbed him, if he was human. But he did not notice. “Armand,” she said again. Then she rose and tottered towards him. “Armand,” she panted once more, clutching his arm, “look at our child. What does it mean? tell me.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002530": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002530", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002531": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002531", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

He coldly but gently loosened her fingers from about his arm and thrust the hand away from him. “Tell me what it means!” she cried despairingly.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002532": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002532", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002533": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002533", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“It means,” he answered lightly, “that the child is not white; it means that you are not white.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002534": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002534", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002535": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002535", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

A quick conception of all that this accusation meant for her nerved her with unwonted courage to deny it. “It is a lie; it is not true, I am white! Look at my hair, it is brown; and my eyes are gray, Armand, you know they are gray. And my skin is fair,” seizing his wrist. “Look at my hand; whiter than yours, Armand,” she laughed hysterically.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002536": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002536", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002537": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002537", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“As white as La Blanche’s,” he returned cruelly; and went away leaving her alone with their child.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002538": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002538", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002539": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002539", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

When she could hold a pen in her hand, she sent a despairing letter to Madame Valmondé.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002540": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002540", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002541": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002541", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“My mother, they tell me I am not white. Armand has told me I am not white. For God’s sake tell them it is not true. You must know it is not true. I shall die. I must die. I cannot be so unhappy, and live.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002542": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002542", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002543": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002543", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The answer that came was brief:

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002544": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002544", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002545": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002545", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“My own Désirée: Come home to Valmondé; back to your mother who loves you. Come with your child.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002546": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002546", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002547": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002547", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

When the letter reached Désirée she went with it to her husband’s study, and laid it open upon the desk before which he sat. She was like a stone image: silent, white, motionless after she placed it there.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002548": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002548", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002549": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002549", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

In silence he ran his cold eyes over the written words.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002550": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002550", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002551": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002551", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

He said nothing. “Shall I go, Armand?” she asked in tones sharp with agonized suspense.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002552": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002552", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002553": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002553", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Yes, go.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002554": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002554", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002555": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002555", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Do you want me to go?”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002556": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002556", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002557": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002557", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Yes, I want you to go.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002558": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002558", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002559": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002559", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

He thought Almighty God had dealt cruelly and unjustly with him; and felt, somehow, that he was paying Him back in kind when he stabbed thus into his wife’s soul. Moreover he no longer loved her, because of the unconscious injury she had brought upon his home and his name.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002560": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002560", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002561": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002561", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She turned away like one stunned by a blow, and walked slowly towards the door, hoping he would call her back.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002562": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002562", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002563": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002563", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Good-by, Armand,” she moaned.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002564": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002564", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002565": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002565", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

He did not answer her. That was his last blow at fate.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002566": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002566", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002567": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002567", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Désirée went in search of her child. Zandrine was pacing the sombre gallery with it. She took the little one from the nurse’s arms with no word of explanation, and descending the steps, walked away, under the live-oak branches.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002568": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002568", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002569": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002569", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

It was an October afternoon; the sun was just sinking. Out in the still fields the negroes were picking cotton.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002570": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002570", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002571": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002571", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Désirée had not changed the thin white garment nor the slippers which she wore. Her hair was uncovered and the sun’s rays brought a golden gleam from its brown meshes. She did not take the broad, beaten road which led to the far-off plantation of Valmondé. She walked across a deserted field, where the stubble bruised her tender feet, so delicately shod, and tore her thin gown to shreds.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002572": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002572", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002573": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002573", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She disappeared among the reeds and willows that grew thick along the banks of the deep, sluggish bayou; and she did not come back again.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002574": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002574", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002575": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002575", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Some weeks later there was a curious scene enacted at L’Abri. In the centre of the smoothly swept back yard was a great bonfire. Armand Aubigny sat in the wide hallway that commanded a view of the spectacle; and it was he who dealt out to a half dozen negroes the material which kept this fire ablaze.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002576": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002576", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002577": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002577", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

A graceful cradle of willow, with all its dainty furbishings, was laid upon the pyre, which had already been fed with the richness of a priceless layette. Then there were silk gowns, and velvet and satin ones added to these; laces, too, and embroideries; bonnets and gloves; for the corbeille had been of rare quality.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002578": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002578", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002579": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002579", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The last thing to go was a tiny bundle of letters; innocent little scribblings that Désirée had sent to him during the days of their espousal. There was the remnant of one back in the drawer from which he took them. But it was not Désirée’s; it was part of an old letter from his mother to his father. He read it. She was thanking God for the blessing of her husband’s love:—

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002580": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002580", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002581": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002581", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“But above all,” she wrote, “night and day, I thank the good God for having so arranged our lives that our dear Armand will never know that his mother, who adores him, belongs to the race that is cursed with the brand of slavery.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002582": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002582", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002583": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002583", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002584": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002584", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

A RESPECTABLE WOMAN

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002585": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002585", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002586": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002586", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Mrs. Baroda was a little provoked to learn that her husband expected his friend, Gouvernail, up to spend a week or two on the plantation.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002587": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002587", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002588": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002588", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

They had entertained a good deal during the winter; much of the time had also been passed in New Orleans in various forms of mild dissipation. She was looking forward to a period of unbroken rest, now, and undisturbed tête-à-tête with her husband, when he informed her that Gouvernail was coming up to stay a week or two.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002589": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002589", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002590": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002590", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

This was a man she had heard much of but never seen. He had been her husband’s college friend; was now a journalist, and in no sense a society man or “a man about town,” which were, perhaps, some of the reasons she had never met him. But she had unconsciously formed an image of him in her mind. She pictured him tall, slim, cynical; with eye-glasses, and his hands in his pockets; and she did not like him. Gouvernail was slim enough, but he wasn’t very tall nor very cynical; neither did he wear eyeglasses nor carry his hands in his pockets. And she rather liked him when he first presented himself.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002591": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002591", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002592": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002592", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

But why she liked him she could not explain satisfactorily to herself when she partly attempted to do so. She could discover in him none of those brilliant and promising traits which Gaston, her husband, had often assured her that he possessed. On the contrary, he sat rather mute and receptive before her chatty eagerness to make him feel at home and in face of Gaston’s frank and wordy hospitality. His manner was as courteous toward her as the most exacting woman could require; but he made no direct appeal to her approval or even esteem.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002593": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002593", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002594": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002594", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Once settled at the plantation he seemed to like to sit upon the wide portico in the shade of one of the big Corinthian pillars, smoking his cigar lazily and listening attentively to Gaston’s experience as a sugar planter.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002595": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002595", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002596": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002596", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“This is what I call living,” he would utter with deep satisfaction, as the air that swept across the sugar field caressed him with its warm and scented velvety touch. It pleased him also to get on familiar terms with the big dogs that came about him, rubbing themselves sociably against his legs. He did not care to fish, and displayed no eagerness to go out and kill grosbecs when Gaston proposed doing so.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002597": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002597", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002598": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002598", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Gouvernail’s personality puzzled Mrs. Baroda, but she liked him. Indeed, he was a lovable, inoffensive fellow. After a few days, when she could understand him no better than at first, she gave over being puzzled and remained piqued. In this mood she left her husband and her guest, for the most part, alone together. Then finding that Gouvernail took no manner of exception to her action, she imposed her society upon him, accompanying him in his idle strolls to the mill and walks along the batture. She persistently sought to penetrate the reserve in which he had unconsciously enveloped himself.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002599": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002599", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002600": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002600", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“When is he going—your friend?” she one day asked her husband. “For my part, he tires me frightfully.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002601": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002601", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002602": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002602", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Not for a week yet, dear. I can’t understand; he gives you no trouble.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002603": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002603", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002604": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002604", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“No. I should like him better if he did; if he were more like others, and I had to plan somewhat for his comfort and enjoyment.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002605": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002605", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002606": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002606", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Gaston took his wife’s pretty face between his hands and looked tenderly and laughingly into her troubled eyes.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002607": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002607", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002608": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002608", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

They were making a bit of toilet sociably together in Mrs. Baroda’s dressing-room.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002609": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002609", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002610": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002610", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“You are full of surprises, ma belle,” he said to her. “Even I can never count upon how you are going to act under given conditions.” He kissed her and turned to fasten his cravat before the mirror.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002611": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002611", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002612": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002612", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Here you are,” he went on, “taking poor Gouvernail seriously and making a commotion over him, the last thing he would desire or expect.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002613": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002613", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002614": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002614", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Commotion!” she hotly resented. “Nonsense! How can you say such a thing? Commotion, indeed! But, you know, you said he was clever.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002615": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002615", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002616": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002616", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“So he is. But the poor fellow is run down by overwork now. That’s why I asked him here to take a rest.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002617": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002617", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002618": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002618", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“You used to say he was a man of ideas,” she retorted, unconciliated. “I expected him to be interesting, at least. I’m going to the city in the morning to have my spring gowns fitted. Let me know when Mr. Gouvernail is gone; I shall be at my Aunt Octavie’s.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002619": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002619", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002620": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002620", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

That night she went and sat alone upon a bench that stood beneath a live oak tree at the edge of the gravel walk.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002621": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002621", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002622": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002622", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She had never known her thoughts or her intentions to be so confused. She could gather nothing from them but the feeling of a distinct necessity to quit her home in the morning.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002623": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002623", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002624": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002624", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Mrs. Baroda heard footsteps crunching the gravel; but could discern in the darkness only the approaching red point of a lighted cigar. She knew it was Gouvernail, for her husband did not smoke. She hoped to remain unnoticed, but her white gown revealed her to him. He threw away his cigar and seated himself upon the bench beside her; without a suspicion that she might object to his presence.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002625": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002625", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002626": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002626", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Your husband told me to bring this to you, Mrs. Baroda,” he said, handing her a filmy, white scarf with which she sometimes enveloped her head and shoulders. She accepted the scarf from him with a murmur of thanks, and let it lie in her lap.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002627": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002627", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002628": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002628", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

He made some commonplace observation upon the baneful effect of the night air at the season. Then as his gaze reached out into the darkness, he murmured, half to himself:

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002629": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002629", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002630": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002630", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“‘Night of south winds—night of the large few stars!
Still nodding night—’”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002631": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002631", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002632": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002632", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She made no reply to this apostrophe to the night, which, indeed, was not addressed to her.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002633": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002633", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002634": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002634", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Gouvernail was in no sense a diffident man, for he was not a self-conscious one. His periods of reserve were not constitutional, but the result of moods. Sitting there beside Mrs. Baroda, his silence melted for the time.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002635": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002635", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002636": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002636", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

He talked freely and intimately in a low, hesitating drawl that was not unpleasant to hear. He talked of the old college days when he and Gaston had been a good deal to each other; of the days of keen and blind ambitions and large intentions. Now there was left with him, at least, a philosophic acquiescence to the existing order—only a desire to be permitted to exist, with now and then a little whiff of genuine life, such as he was breathing now.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002637": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002637", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002638": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002638", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Her mind only vaguely grasped what he was saying. Her physical being was for the moment predominant. She was not thinking of his words, only drinking in the tones of his voice. She wanted to reach out her hand in the darkness and touch him with the sensitive tips of her fingers upon the face or the lips. She wanted to draw close to him and whisper against his cheek—she did not care what—as she might have done if she had not been a respectable woman.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002639": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002639", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002640": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002640", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

The stronger the impulse grew to bring herself near him, the further, in fact, did she draw away from him. As soon as she could do so without an appearance of too great rudeness, she rose and left him there alone.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002641": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002641", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002642": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002642", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Before she reached the house, Gouvernail had lighted a fresh cigar and ended his apostrophe to the night.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002643": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002643", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002644": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002644", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Mrs. Baroda was greatly tempted that night to tell her husband—who was also her friend—of this folly that had seized her. But she did not yield to the temptation. Beside being a respectable woman she was a very sensible one; and she knew there are some battles in life which a human being must fight alone.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002645": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002645", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002646": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002646", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

When Gaston arose in the morning, his wife had already departed. She had taken an early morning train to the city. She did not return till Gouvernail was gone from under her roof.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002647": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002647", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002648": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002648", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

There was some talk of having him back during the summer that followed. That is, Gaston greatly desired it; but this desire yielded to his wife’s strenuous opposition.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002649": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002649", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002650": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002650", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

However, before the year ended, she proposed, wholly from herself, to have Gouvernail visit them again. Her husband was surprised and delighted with the suggestion coming from her.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002651": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002651", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002652": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002652", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“I am glad, chère amie, to know that you have finally overcome your dislike for him; truly he did not deserve it.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002653": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002653", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002654": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002654", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Oh,” she told him, laughingly, after pressing a long, tender kiss upon his lips, “I have overcome everything! you will see. This time I shall be very nice to him.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002655": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002655", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002656": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002656", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002657": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002657", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

THE KISS

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002658": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002658", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002659": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002659", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

It was still quite light out of doors, but inside with the curtains drawn and the smouldering fire sending out a dim, uncertain glow, the room was full of deep shadows.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002660": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002660", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002661": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002661", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Brantain sat in one of these shadows; it had overtaken him and he did not mind. The obscurity lent him courage to keep his eyes fastened as ardently as he liked upon the girl who sat in the firelight.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002662": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002662", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002663": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002663", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She was very handsome, with a certain fine, rich coloring that belongs to the healthy brune type. She was quite composed, as she idly stroked the satiny coat of the cat that lay curled in her lap, and she occasionally sent a slow glance into the shadow where her companion sat. They were talking low, of indifferent things which plainly were not the things that occupied their thoughts. She knew that he loved her—a frank, blustering fellow without guile enough to conceal his feelings, and no desire to do so. For two weeks past he had sought her society eagerly and persistently. She was confidently waiting for him to declare himself and she meant to accept him. The rather insignificant and unattractive Brantain was enormously rich; and she liked and required the entourage which wealth could give her.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002664": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002664", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002665": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002665", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

During one of the pauses between their talk of the last tea and the next reception the door opened and a young man entered whom Brantain knew quite well. The girl turned her face toward him. A stride or two brought him to her side, and bending over her chair—before she could suspect his intention, for she did not realize that he had not seen her visitor—he pressed an ardent, lingering kiss upon her lips.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002666": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002666", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002667": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002667", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Brantain slowly arose; so did the girl arise, but quickly, and the newcomer stood between them, a little amusement and some defiance struggling with the confusion in his face.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002668": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002668", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002669": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002669", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“I believe,” stammered Brantain, “I see that I have stayed too long. I—I had no idea—that is, I must wish you good-by.” He was clutching his hat with both hands, and probably did not perceive that she was extending her hand to him, her presence of mind had not completely deserted her; but she could not have trusted herself to speak.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002670": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002670", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002671": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002671", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Hang me if I saw him sitting there, Nattie! I know it’s deuced awkward for you. But I hope you’ll forgive me this once—this very first break. Why, what’s the matter?”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002672": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002672", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002673": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002673", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Don’t touch me; don’t come near me,” she returned angrily. “What do you mean by entering the house without ringing?”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002674": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002674", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002675": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002675", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“I came in with your brother, as I often do,” he answered coldly, in self-justification. “We came in the side way. He went upstairs and I came in here hoping to find you. The explanation is simple enough and ought to satisfy you that the misadventure was unavoidable. But do say that you forgive me, Nathalie,” he entreated, softening.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002676": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002676", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002677": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002677", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Forgive you! You don’t know what you are talking about. Let me pass. It depends upon—a good deal whether I ever forgive you.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002678": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002678", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002679": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002679", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

At that next reception which she and Brantain had been talking about she approached the young man with a delicious frankness of manner when she saw him there.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002680": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002680", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002681": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002681", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Will you let me speak to you a moment or two, Mr. Brantain?” she asked with an engaging but perturbed smile. He seemed extremely unhappy; but when she took his arm and walked away with him, seeking a retired corner, a ray of hope mingled with the almost comical misery of his expression. She was apparently very outspoken.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002682": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002682", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002683": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002683", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Perhaps I should not have sought this interview, Mr. Brantain; but—but, oh, I have been very uncomfortable, almost miserable since that little encounter the other afternoon. When I thought how you might have misinterpreted it, and believed things”—hope was plainly gaining the ascendancy over misery in Brantain’s round, guileless face—“Of course, I know it is nothing to you, but for my own sake I do want you to understand that Mr. Harvy is an intimate friend of long standing. Why, we have always been like cousins—like brother and sister, I may say. He is my brother’s most intimate associate and often fancies that he is entitled to the same privileges as the family. Oh, I know it is absurd, uncalled for, to tell you this; undignified even,” she was almost weeping, “but it makes so much difference to me what you think of—of me.” Her voice had grown very low and agitated. The misery had all disappeared from Brantain’s face.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002684": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002684", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002685": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002685", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Then you do really care what I think, Miss Nathalie? May I call you Miss Nathalie?” They turned into a long, dim corridor that was lined on either side with tall, graceful plants. They walked slowly to the very end of it. When they turned to retrace their steps Brantain’s face was radiant and hers was triumphant.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002686": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002686", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002687": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002687", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Harvy was among the guests at the wedding; and he sought her out in a rare moment when she stood alone.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002688": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002688", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002689": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002689", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“Your husband,” he said, smiling, “has sent me over to kiss you.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002690": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002690", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002691": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002691", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

A quick blush suffused her face and round polished throat. “I suppose it’s natural for a man to feel and act generously on an occasion of this kind. He tells me he doesn’t want his marriage to interrupt wholly that pleasant intimacy which has existed between you and me. I don’t know what you’ve been telling him,” with an insolent smile, “but he has sent me here to kiss you.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002692": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002692", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002693": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002693", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

She felt like a chess player who, by the clever handling of his pieces, sees the game taking the course intended. Her eyes were bright and tender with a smile as they glanced up into his; and her lips looked hungry for the kiss which they invited.

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002694": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002694", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002695": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002695", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

“But, you know,” he went on quietly, “I didn’t tell him so, it would have seemed ungrateful, but I can tell you. I’ve stopped kissing women; it’s dangerous.”

" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002696": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002696", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "
" }, "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002697": { "role": "text", "title": "$:/plugins/twpub/3ae35ef49641be75/text/000002697", "type": "text/vnd.twpub", "text": "

Well, she had Brantain and his million left. A person can’t have everything in this world; and it was a little unreasonable of her to expect it.
